body_html:
@Rahul-Venugopal

  1. There are many ways to install Caffe2. setup.py is a common Python installation method; it really just calls cmake and make behind the scenes, but has some extra logic to locate the current active site-packages and can be used to make pip packages. It ignores other files in the repo, so running cmake before setup.py will not affect setup.py . Also, to build Caffe2 along with Pytorch you actually have to use "FULL_CAFFE2=1 python setup.py install" instead of the comamnd above.

  2. Search the output of the build command that you used for "Summary", and it should have a line for CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX which is where Caffe2 will be installed. If you called cmake and then make, then this is the output of the cmake command; but if you called setup.py then this will be in the output of setup.py

This link https://caffe2.ai/docs/faq.html#why-do-i-get-import-errors-in-python-when-i-try-to-use-caffe2 has some good info on how python installations work.
body_text:
@Rahul-Venugopal


There are many ways to install Caffe2. setup.py is a common Python installation method; it really just calls cmake and make behind the scenes, but has some extra logic to locate the current active site-packages and can be used to make pip packages. It ignores other files in the repo, so running cmake before setup.py will not affect setup.py . Also, to build Caffe2 along with Pytorch you actually have to use "FULL_CAFFE2=1 python setup.py install" instead of the comamnd above.


Search the output of the build command that you used for "Summary", and it should have a line for CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX which is where Caffe2 will be installed. If you called cmake and then make, then this is the output of the cmake command; but if you called setup.py then this will be in the output of setup.py


This link https://caffe2.ai/docs/faq.html#why-do-i-get-import-errors-in-python-when-i-try-to-use-caffe2 has some good info on how python installations work.
body:
@Rahul-Venugopal 

1. There are many ways to install Caffe2. setup.py is a common Python installation method; it really just calls cmake and make behind the scenes, but has some extra logic to locate the current active site-packages and can be used to make pip packages. It ignores other files in the repo, so running cmake before setup.py will not affect setup.py . Also, to build Caffe2 along with Pytorch you actually have to use "FULL_CAFFE2=1 python setup.py install" instead of the comamnd above.

2. Search the output of the build command that you used for "Summary", and it should have a line for CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX which is where Caffe2 will be installed. If you called cmake and then make, then this is the output of the cmake command; but if you called setup.py then this will be in the output of setup.py

This link https://caffe2.ai/docs/faq.html#why-do-i-get-import-errors-in-python-when-i-try-to-use-caffe2 has some good info on how python installations work.
